title: euBusinessGraph: Enabling the European Business Graph for Innovative Data Products and Services

author: Matteo Palmonari, University of Milano - Bicocca

segmentation: So it's still me.
So I'm representing here a different project.
The project before I'm the coordinator here, we're partners and basically this is again an innovation action.
This is a project about enabling the European business graph for innovative data products and services.
So the main and the coordinator of this project is.
The SINTEF Norway, or also represented here.
So we chart the high level project goals.
Basically we want to make company data more easy to access by third parties.
Second, we want to make it easier for company data providers to share their data.
An also, in particular for data driven application and to make it easier for data consumers to find.
An access company data.
So company data are information about companies.
They are very important for several applications like for example risk computation for banks or like competitor analysis.
All this kind of business cases.
So the goal in this project is the creation of this marketplace for company related data.
So one of the result is the creation of these business graph which is a graph of company data.
In particular, one of the results here.
In the project I would like to advertise here is the ontology for describing company data.
'cause this was done really with the in depth.
Effort by several partners with experts from companies that deal with company data like everyday and experts from the Semantic Web.
So I really suggest to look into this ontology if you want to describe this kind of information.
We also developed a set of tools and services that of course support both the creation of the business graph, the analysis of the business graph, an services that are built on top of them.
Right and finally the last product almost there.
We still have one month to finish completely, but it's almost there.
It's the data marketplace where you can really look into this web page and search for this information right.
This is if you work like for example, with data journalist that data journalists are always starving for this kind of information, right?
'cause a lot of politically relevant analytics?
I also based on like data about companies, so I've seen like many people looking for that and there was no.
Any Anne Anne and there was no source that provided this information, so this is exactly this source.
The source is the original source is our National Register gazetteers as specialized register website and social media accounts.

These are examples of representation of company data different from different partners, but we made an effort to identify the common information that these partners could share so the initial data that you will find.
In the graph, will contain data from those partners for different legislations.
And then of course we have several business cases that you can read about accessing to the website of the project and several graph services example, which I will.

It's more about the proper, so here the very difficult issue here is to define the identity criteria for the companies and the identification numbers becausw each company may be identified a using a different systems of identifiers.
So this ontology did a really good job in evaluating.
All those are identifiers through how Europe to understand how to identify.
So it's not really a matter of large number of of classes, but more the properties that you need to use to describe this.
